instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2330: What is 820-2330? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.C7771: What is C7771? Tantalum capacitor on 820-2330 and 820-2532 logic boards that often dies and causes PP1V05_S5_MCP or PP1V05_S5 to be 0.331v instead of 1.05v. If heating this cap restores voltage to this rail, replace.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Green Light but does not turn on
threads.message:
A friends old piece of crap that went dead. No water or signs of drops.

He had a battery with over 2500 cycles, replaced it with a compatible one and went dead. To charge the battery he was connecting the charger and then the battery but it didn't turn ON, the Mac didn't charge it with the battery connected from the start.

Now it has a green light, G3H is 7.9 - 8V, and <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR> is 1.10V. Any ideas ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Green Light but does not turn on
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> should be about 12.6V, check sense resistors......  Charger is original 85W???

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Green Light but does not turn on
threads.message: My guess is a combination of a dead battery and a fake 85W charger. Is PPBUS without the battery installed 12.6V? Are you using a REAL 85W charger?
